title: 114_s1600
content: The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" allows citizens of designated countries to have privacy act remedies extended to them. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends civil remedies to covered persons for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Privacy Act. These remedies are exclusive under this section. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" provides exclusive civil remedies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Privacy Act, allowing covered persons to bring actions against designated Federal agencies. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under the Privacy Act when pursuing civil remedies. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, can designate covered countries. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has an agreement with the US for privacy protections in preventing criminal offenses. The Attorney General may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has an agreement with the United States for privacy protections in preventing criminal offenses. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with the agreement for sharing information to prevent criminal offenses. The Attorney General can revoke a foreign country's designation as a "covered country" if it fails to comply with information-sharing agreements or impedes the transfer of information to the United States. The Attorney General determines which agencies are designated as "Federal agency or component" for this purpose, limited to the Department of Justice or its components. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies or components for information-sharing agreements with covered countries, requiring concurrence from relevant agency heads. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies or components for information-sharing agreements with covered countries based on law enforcement interests of the United States. The determinations are published in the Federal Register and are nonreviewable. The Attorney General designates Federal agencies or components for information-sharing agreements with covered countries based on U.S. law enforcement interests. Determinations are published in the Federal Register and are nonreviewable. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over any claims arising under this section. In this Act, definitions are provided for terms such as "agency," "covered country," "covered person," and "covered record." The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over any claims arising under this section. The term "covered record" for a covered person has the same meaning as a record for an individual under section 552a of title 5, United States Code, once transferred to a designated Federal agency for criminal offense purposes. The Act allows designated Federal agencies to access covered records for criminal offense purposes without waiving privileges or requiring disclosure of classified information. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
